message.content:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: 
private static List<Employee> parseCSVFileAsList() throws IOException {
    CSVReader reader = new CSVReader(new FileReader("employees.csv"), ',');
    List<Employee> emps = new ArrayList<Employee>();
    List<String[]> records = reader.readAll();
    Iterator<String[]> iterator = records.iterator();
    String[] header = iterator.next();
    while (iterator.hasNext()) {
        String[] record = iterator.next();
        Employee emp = new Employee();
        for (int i = 0; i < record.length; i++) {
            if (i < header.length) {
                switch (header[i]) {
                    case "ID":
                        emp.setId(record[i]);
                        break;
                    case "Name":
                        emp.setName(record[i]);
                        break;
                    case "Role":
                        emp.setRole(record[i]);
                        break;
                    case "Salary":
                        emp.setSalary(record[i]);
                        break;
                    default:
                        // handle additional columns here
                        break;
                }
            } else {
                // handle additional columns here
            }
        }
        emps.add(emp);
    }
    reader.close();
    return emps;
}
<<<explanation>>>: In this code, we read the CSV file and store the header row in the `header` array. Then, for each record in the CSV file, we iterate over the columns and check if the column name matches any of the known headers. If it does, we set the corresponding property of the `Employee` object. If it doesn't match any known headers, you can handle additional columns as needed.
